NewWords.WordPhrase: (infml) very active or busy 繁忙；活动多
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I've been on the go all week, preparing my thesis.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. deal successfully (with sb. / sth. difficult) （成功地）对付；妥善处理
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Health psychologists study how people cope with stress.

NewWords.WordPhrase: begin (a task); start (doing sth.) 开始；着手
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The school authorities must set about finding solutions to the campus security problems.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  free (sth.) from knots, complexities, etc. 解开…的纠结，理顺
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She untangled her hair from the hair-drier.

NewWords.WordPhrase: large amounts/a large amount of 许多的，大量的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The key to staying healthy and strong when backpacking is to eat large quantities of energy-rich foods.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the state of being idle 闲散；无所事事
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Idleness is the parent of all vice.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. make a slave of (sb.) 使成为奴隶，奴役
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Her beauty enslaved many young men.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  puzzling 令人困惑的；费解的   bewilder vt.  puzzle; confuse 使困惑；使糊涂
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I don't know how to solve this bewildering question.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (pl millennia or millenniums) period of a thousand years 一千年
gradually reduce the amount of (sth. valuable); damage or destroy 吞噬；侵蚀；毁坏
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. All these car expenses are eating into our savings.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  汽车
n. （单复同）飞机；航空器
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The goal of air traffic control is to minimize the risk of aircraft collisions.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  taking or needing much time 耗费时间的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Starting a new business, however small, is a time-consuming exercise.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. crossing the Atlantic; on or from the other side of the Atlantic 横越大西洋的；在（或来自）大西洋彼岸的
n.  organized journey or voyage with a particular aim 远行；探险；远征
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Scott died while he was on an expedition to the Antarctic in 1912.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. conference of members of a profession, political party; generally accepted social behavior 大会；惯例，常规
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She was a speaker at the Railway Workers' Convention in 1956.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. work hard and untiringly; move with difficulty or pain 辛苦地劳作；艰难地行动
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We toiled away all afternoon to get the house ready for our guests.

NewWords.WordPhrase: in actual fact; really 事实上；实际上
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Some famous private schools are theoretically open to the public, but in reality are attended by those who can afford the fees.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v.  increase in number or quantity; add a number to itself a particular number of times 增加；乘
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The weeds just multiplied, and before long the garden was a jungle.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. take care of the appearance of (oneself) by dressing neatly 梳妆
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He groomed himself carefully in front of the mirror.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 便携式电脑
n.  set of symptoms which together indicate a particular disease or abnormal condition 综合病症；综合症状
n.  heavy load 负担，重负
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Some farmers are complaining about the heavy burden of taxation.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 传真件；传真系统
n. an electronic communication system in which spoken messages are recorded and stored for later playback for the intended recipient 语音邮件
n. 软件
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He is applying for a position of software engineer.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 小故障，失灵
n. a small part, bit, amount or proportion (of sth.) 小部分，一点儿，少许
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Only a small fraction of the population lived in that remote area.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 大量涌入
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Many football fans poured into the stadium to have a look at their favorite football players.

NewWords.WordPhrase: abbr.  compact-disc read-only memory 光盘只读存储器
v. increase rapidly in numbers; produce new growth or offspring rapidly （数量）激增；（迅速地）增殖
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. In recent years commercial, cultural, travel and other contacts have proliferated between Europe and China.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 少数，少量；一把
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Only a handful of graduates have not found jobs so far.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. newspaper or periodical, esp. one that is serious and deals with a specialized subject 日报；(学术) 期刊
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. the Journal of Medical Science

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  出版（物）；发表，公布
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The collection of the theses is ready for publication.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. (of a degree, rank, etc.) given as an honor（指学位、级别等）荣誉的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He's the honorary chairman of the committee.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. person in charge of a museum, an art gallery, etc. （博物馆、美术馆等的）馆长
n. scientific study of insects 昆虫学
a.  involving comparison or comparing 比较的；相比的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Some sociologists have carried out large-scale historical-comparative studies.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. scientific study of the structure, form and distribution of animals 动物学
be equal to; add up to 相当于；总计
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. In 1959 the combined value of U.S. imports and exports amounted to less than 9 percent of the country's gross domestic product.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  very small in size or amount 极小的；极少的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Only a minute amount of money is needed.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (usu. pl)（某学科的）知识边缘，（探索活动的）新领域；边境
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. To open up the space frontier, NASA will try to lower the cost of access to Earth orbit.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. pressure or worry resulting from mental or physical distress, difficult circumstances, etc. 压力，重压  vt. put stress, pressure, or strain on 加压力于；使紧张
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There is enough evidence to suggest that job stress may increase a man's risk of dying from heart disease.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. state of being economically successful; state of being successful or rich （经济的）繁荣；成功，富足
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. War brings no prosperity to the great mass of ordinary citizens.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v.  do sth. for (sb.) as a favor or small service（为…）效劳； 帮（…的）忙
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. If you ever need help with the baby-sitting, I'd be happy to oblige.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  lack of satisfaction 不满足；不满意
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The strikers were a sign of discontent with poor pay.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. quantity that is more than enough; plenty 丰富；丰裕
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The visitor to Oxford has an abundance of sights to see.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. bewilderment or embarrassment 惶惑；迷乱
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I explained the question to him three times, but there was still a look of confusion on his face.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 简略的表达方式；速记（法）
a. temporarily without a paid job 未被雇用的；失业的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He was unemployed for two months after leaving college.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. 外围地；边缘地；次要地    peripheral a.
n. 经济；经济制度；节约
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His views on knowledge economy have been accepted with unanimity.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (forecast or forecasted) vt. tell in advance; predict 预报；预测
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The means of forecasting natural disasters, such as floods, and hurricanes, have improved immensely as science and technology have advanced.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. decided by oneself, without being influenced or ordered by other people 自己强加的，自愿承担的
n. person who offers to do sth. without being compelled or paid 自愿者；志愿兵
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Some students served as volunteers to help the old and disabled in the community in their spare time.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. way of seeing or understanding sth.; ability to notice and understand things 看法，观念；感知，感觉
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Aesthetics is a branch of philosophy concerned with the essence and perception of beauty and ugliness.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 社会学
ad. 不均衡地；不平坦地；不平整地   uneven a.
n. unmarried people 未婚的人们
n. 厮守“空巢”者（尤指子女不在身边的人）
a. 学龄前的；学前的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. pre-school children

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. care for and educate (a child); encourage the growth of (sth.); nourish 养育；培育；滋养
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Parents want to know the best way to nurture and raise their children to adulthood.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.（单复同） child or children of a particular person or couple 孩子，子女
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Heredity is the process of transmitting biological traits from parents to offsprings through genes.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 性别
n.  instrument or device for a specific purpose 用具；器具
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The Energy Department has set efficiency standards for new home appliances.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. causing fear; shocking; terrible 骇人听闻的；令人震惊的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. When will this appalling war end?

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (instance of) extreme scarcity of food in a region 饥荒
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. China has succeeded in feeding its people; national attention to equity, agriculture, and birth control has significantly reduced the threat of famine.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. found or distributed over a large area 遍布的；大面积的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The landscape of the American West was dramatically altered during the 20th century as a result of the widespread construction of dams along major rivers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. cause (sth.) to occur or arouse (a feeling, etc.) 使产生；引起（某种感情等）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. People's concern over genetically modified food has provoked a global debate that shows no sign of ending soon.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 各种的；各种各样的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. People change their mind for a variety of reasons.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (of computer) fixed number of binary digits, often representing a single character 字节；位组
a.  state of being pleased or satisfied 满意；满足
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Your approval gives me much gratification.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. make (sth.) more efficient and effective 使合理化，使效率更高；使成流线型
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Corporate mergers can result in job losses because management combines and streamlines departments within the newly merged companies.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (process of) growing; development 生长；发展
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The area has seen a rapid population growth.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. doorkeeper 看门人，看守人
a. of the home, household or family; of or inside a particular country 家庭的；家务的；国内的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Police and hospital records indicate that the majority of victims of domestic violence are women.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 儿童保育；儿童照管
a. connected to and controlled by a computer 联机的，在线的
n. tradesman who sells by retail 零售商
n. an assembly, place, radio program etc. for the discussion of public matters or current questions 论坛；讨论会；（广播、电视的）专题讨论节目
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The school authorities will provide a forum where problems can be discussed.

NewWords.WordPhrase: appear, develop, grow, etc. quickly or suddenly 迅速发展（或生长）；突然出现
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. New professional training schools sprang up all over the country.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. producing no result; useless; pointless 无效的；无用的；无意义的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It was futile to continue the negotiations.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. turn (sb./sth.) aside from a course, direction, etc. into another 使转向；转移
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Some dams divert the flow of river water into a pipeline, canal, or channel.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi.  (arose, arisen) appear; become evident 出现；呈现
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Challenging ethical issues have arisen in science and medicine.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. lack of sth. needed; deficiency 缺少；不足；短缺
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The world is facing the prospect of water shortages caused by population growth, uneven supplies of water, pollution, and other factors.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. too large an amount 过量，过度
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A surfeit of food makes one sick.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. push or force into a small place 将…塞入， 硬塞进
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It's dangerous for too many people to be crammed into a bus.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. sweets or chocolate 糖果；巧克力
vt. avoid (sth. unpleasant or unwanted); manage not to do (sth. which should be done) 躲开，避开；逃避
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The released criminal always tries to evade the police.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (usu. pl) boundaries; limits; borders 范围；界限；边界
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. This is outside the confines of human knowledge.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. in a reasonable way; moderately 合理地；适度地   reasonable a.
disconnect (electricity, etc.) 关，切断（电源等）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Be sure to switch off the lights when you leave home.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 手机
命定；注定
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He thought that he was doomed to spend the rest of his life in a wheelchair.
